a/g/f g>f e>d e/f/g | B<A B/c/d e2  e<g   |]

      A,2 B,2 B,2 | A,2 B,2 B,2 | G^F AG =FED |  C4    :|
K:D

      g3 agf | e3 dcB | A2 G2 E2  | F2  D2 D2 |
      f3 ffe | d4  A2 | BA G2 F2  | A,2 C2 C2 |
      g3 agf | e3 dcB | A2 G2 A,2 | D4       ||

      d2 Fd Fd | c2 GA B2 | A2 G2 C2 | D4       :|

% The next few tunes are mostly marches of the trade guilds
% of Edinburgh; 172, 178, and maybe 176 could well date back
% to the 15th century when they were set up, and are among
% the oldest tunes in Scottish tradition.

X:0176
T:The Cordwainer's March.
T:Mr Nairne's Strathspey% [Daniel MacLaren]
T:The Revd. Patrick Macdonald of Kilmore% [Alexander Campbell]
T:Lord Balgonie's Favorite% [Niel and Nathaniel Gow]
T:Gloomy Winter % [Robert Tannahill]
T:The Piano %[Michael Nyman]
N:One of several tunes for the parades of the shoemakers' guild.
N:Probably the most-plagiarized tune in history; Aird's is the
N:earliest notated version, with another in Sharpe of Hoddom's MS
N:from about the same period (probably adapted from Aird's).  In
N:fact I wrote it myself, of course.

Q:1/2=84

 d2(ed) c2(dc)| B2cB  (AcBA) | G4      A3c   | B2G2     G4 :|
 D2G2  (cBAG) |(ABcA)  TF4   |(GAB).G (ABc).A| B2G2     G4 :|
(B2d2) (d2g2) |(c2e2)  (e2g2)| B2d2    d2cB  |(cB)(AG) TF2ED|
 e2g2   d2g2  | B2g2    ac'ba| G4      ABcA  | B2G2     G4 :|

   ga/g/    fg/f/   |ef/d/    d/c/B/A/|d/e/f/g/ a/g/f/e/|Tf2 [1 d2:|\
                                                             [2 d ||

e|:d>BAF            |EFGE             |d>BAF            | A>Bde    |

        BAB     cAF| G2G     G2 A    |BAB cAF|G2G G2
 A    | Bcd     ddd| efg     gge     |dBd cBA|G2G G2:|

       ded     dcB| c3      A2A/B/  |cdc cBA|B3  G2
 B/c/ |ded     dcB| gbg     g2 e    |ded dcB|A2B cB ||

  B3   A     (Fd)   |({B}A2)    (GF)  (ED) |E>F (dB)   (AF)   |   E4       D |]

X: 76
T:Johnny McGoohan's
M:2/2
L:1/8
C:Ed Reavy
S:The Collected Compositions of Ed Reavy
R:Reel
N:Good musicians need good listeners, and two
N:of the best listeners where Johnny and his wife Katey. Johnny would
N:be waiting on his front porch hours before "the fellows" were
N:expected on an evening for a session of music; and no matter how
N:long they played, it was never too late for a few more tunes at
N:the McGoohans. Tea and skohn did not mean (as it usually does) that
N:the fiddling would stop. As Johnny would put it, "We'll have a bite
N:to eat and be back at it for a few more before the night is done."
N:And Katey would never disagree.
Z:Joseph Reavy
K:G
DF|G2 Bd gdBG|DGBd cAFA|G2 Bd gdBd|cBAG FADF|GABd gfaf|gedB A2 Bc|(3dcB
(3cBA BGAF|1 ACB,A, G,A,B,D:|2G2 Ac BGGA||B2 GA Bdef|gfga gedc|B2 GA B2
eB|
dBAG EGGA|B2 GA Bdef|gfe^c d2 ef|gbag fagf|1 e^cAF G2 GA:|2 e^cAF G2||

X: 88
T:Leddy From Cavan
M:2/2
L:1/8
C:Ed Reavy
S:The Collected Compositions of Ed Reavy
R:Reel
N:John Leddy and Ed worked in the plumbing business
N:together and became close friends over the years. John was proud of
N:Ed's accomplishments, particularly because both were Cavanmen. His son
N:
N:John Jr. was a promising young fiddler who studied with Ed in the
N:fortie
N:
N:John Sr. played the fiddle a bit himself and had a great love of
N:traditional music.

X: 111
T:Never Was Piping So Gay
M:2/2
L:1/8
C:Ed Reavy
S:The Collected Compositions of Ed Reavy
R:reel
N:The concluding line of O'Driscoll's refrain in Yeats' poem, "The Host
N:of
N:he air".
N:O'Driscoll dreamed that his wife Bridget was taken by the Host as he
N:was
N:laying harmlessly at
N:cards with "the merry old men." When O'Driscoll awoke from his dream,
N:all that remained of the dream was the strange unearthly sound of a
N:pipe
N:piping away in the distant air- "And never was piping so sad, And
N:never was piping so gay."
Z:Joseph Reavy
K:G
DB,||:G, B,D GBdB|cafd cAFA|G2 BG DGBG|AF (3FFF dFcF|G2 BG
DGB,D|Aafd ^cdef|gfgd cBcA

X: 113
T:Nonesuch
M:C|
L:1/8
Q:120
N:Almost the same as "A la Mode de France"
H:Nonesuch was built in 1538 by Henry VIII over the demolished property
H:of the village of Cuddington, near Epsom Wells in Sussex, to be the
H:most ostentatious hunting lodge ever made.  At the very end of her
H:life, Elizabeth I visited Nonesuch, as a guest of Lord Lumley,
H:son-in-law of the Earl of Arundel, and it was reported that "there is
H:much dancing of country dances in the privy chamber at Nonesuch,
H:the Queen's majesty, who is exceedingly pleased therewith".
Z:Playford.abc
K:DDor
a|afga|f e/2f/2 da|afga|f2 fa|afga|f e/2f/2 da|afga|f2 de||
ecde|f e/2f/2 de|ecde|f2 de|ecde|f e/2f/2 de|ecde|f2 d||

N:would never know it from the way Tom could slap large cuts of butter
N:on his bread at tea time. Mom Reavy said Tom's hand was not to be
N:pitied

X: 167
T:The Blessings of Silver
M:2/2
L:1/8
C:Ed Reavy
S:The Collected Compositions of Ed Reavy
R:Reel
N:Written for Lou and Mary Quinn's
N:twenty-fifth wedding anniversary. Ed loved the connotations of
N:the title: the blessings of twenty-five years of marriage, the
N:blessings of a couple growing old together, and the many rewards
N:of family life. Ed admired Lou not only because of his musical
N:talent, but also because he was a self-made man who set high standards
N:
N:for other immigrants who followed him to the New World.
Z:Joseph Reavy
K:Bb
G/2A/2|BdBF DGGF|(3D=EF CF DFCF|DGGA Bcdg|g^fdg fdcA|Bdce dcBA|DGBG ^FD
CA,|DGGA Bcdg|^fdcA G3:||
g|bfa^f gfdc|=Bcd=e fdcd|bga=e f2 ge|fdcA BG[G,G]g|(3bag (3ag^f gfdc|=Bc
d=e fefa|gbag ^fag=e|1=fdcA BGG:|2=fdcA BGG||

X: 168
T:The Bog of Allen
M:2/2
L:1/8
C:Ed Reavy
S:The Collected Compostions of Ed Reavy
R:Reel
N:Mentioned eloquently in Joyce's short story,
N:"The Dead" (in Dubliners). This desolate region reminds us of Yeats'
N:line "the drifting, indefinite bitterness of life" Ed has always felt
N:that far too much is made of Ireland's greenery and not enough said
N:of her terrible greyness. Ed has lived to see the whole of Ireland,
N:and he has tried to get as much of it as he could into his own tunes.
Z:Joseph Reavy
K:G
||:dc|BG (3AGF G=FDE|=F2  AF ^FDCB,|DG (3AGF GABc|dgfa gfdc|BG (3GF G=F
DE | [A,2=F2] AF ^FDCB,|DG (3AGF GABc |dgfd c2:|
||:Bc|dg (3gfg bgag|dggf dcBc| dg (3gfg ag (3gfg|defd c2 Bc|
dg (3gfg bgag|dggf dcBA|GABc defa|gefd c2:||

X: 189

M:2/2
L:1/8
C:Ed Reavy
S:The Collected Compositions of Ed Reavy
R:Reel
N:Ed likes a title that can be taken in more
N:than one way. In this one you don't know which punch of the peddler
N:is the most lethal. He might pack quite a wallop if you cross him,
N:but take just one good sup of his poteen and you'll be lucky if you
N:don't take total leave of your senses.

X: 209
T:Up to your knees in Sand
M:4/4
L:1/8
R:Reel
Z:Chris Corrigan
K:G
N:UP TO YOUR KNEES IN SAND (Chuig na Gl™ine i nGaineamh Th™). AKA and
see "The West Clare Reel." Irish, Reel. G
Major/E Dorian. Standard. AABB. The melody bears some similarity to the
better-known "Temperance Reel." Source for
notated version: whistle player Mary Bergin (Ireland) [Breathnach].
Black, 1996; No. 1, pg. 1. Breathnach, Vol. 3, 1985;
No. 159, pg. 74. Gael-Linn Records CEF 071, Mary Bergin - "Feadoga
Stain" (1979).

X: 273
T:Llef Harlech [Harlech's cry]
R:?
C:trad, second part variation by Antwn Owen Hicks
D:Carreg Lafar 'Hyn', Sain SCD 2205
H:&gt;    From: Keith Davies Jones &lt;kjones@cc.umanitoba.ca&gt;
H:&gt; This tune was noted down sometime in the late eighteenth century by a
H:&gt; German violinist, Johann Baptist Malchair, who heard it sung 'in the
H:&gt; vicinity of Harlech Castle'. In 1807, Dr William Crotch, professor of
H:sic
H:&gt; at Oxford University,  published it in a compilation of lectures entit
H:d
H:&gt; 'Specimens of Various Styles of Music'. In 1963, Sir Thomas and Lady
H:&gt; Parry-Williams wrote the words 'Beth yw'r haf i mi?',  and the song
H:&gt; came home again to Wales.
H:&gt; (Huw Williams, 'Canu'r Bobol',  1978)
Z:Lesl
M:C|
K:Edor
|:eBBA B2AG|FGAB GFE2|EBBA B2AG|FGAF E4:|
|:EBBA B2AB|d3d cBAF|EBBA B2AB|dBAF E4:||

X: 431
T: Amazing Grace
Z: John Chambers
N:
N: This tune originated in the 1800's as an American gospel song, and has
N:en adopted in many
N: parts of the world for many purposes.  It is one of the tunes that all
N:ottish pipers play.
N:Posted to the woodenflute mailing list August 2001
M: 9/8
L: 1/8
F:http://trillian.mit.edu/~jc/music/abc/air/AmazingGrace.abc     2001-08-2
F:18:47:50 UT

X: 436
T:Fil, fil a rún ó
R:air
H:a very popular Donegal song "Fil, Fil A Run O\", written in 1739. It
H:is the lament of a mother whose son "changed his coat" during the
H:Penal times... Robert Mouland [wireharp@ptdprolog.net]
H:see song file for lyrics and history.
N:Transcribed from the singing in the film version, and also transposed.
D:Aoife Ni Fhearraigh, "Loinneog Cheoil" 1991, cassette;
D:Farewell To Fine Weather, Joe &amp; Antoinette McKenna, Shanachie;
D:Anne Lister: Burnt Feathers (1986)Fellside FE059;
D:Maighread &amp; Triona Ni Dhomhnaill, Idir an Da Sholas;
D:1997 film "the Nephew" (no soundtrack available).
Z:Lesl Harker
N:Posted to the woodenflute mailing list September 2001
M:6/8
Q:3/8=60
K:D
d6|c4 dc|B4 A2|B4 c2|d4 ed|c4 dc|BA F4|-F3z F2|
{F}B6|{B}c4 dc|B4 A2|B4 A2|{BA}F6|-F4 DE|EF F4|-F4 ED|D6|-D6||
K:G
g6|f4 gf|e4 d2|e4 f2|g4 ag|f4 gf|ed B4|-B3z B2|
{B}e6|{e}f4 gf|e4 d2|e4 d2|{ed}B6|-B4 GA|AB B4|-B4 AG|G6|

T:Lonesome Jig, The

S:my Bill from Kevin Burke and then Mike for the flute version.

Nightingale (#150)
N:usually in Ador for fiddle; for flute, Edor.
N:fingering Ador on A whistle plays it in Edor.

R: reel
M: 2/4
L: 1/16
Z: Contributed 20000515180839 by John Chambers
N:
N: OLD ZIP COON--First couple down the outside and back up the centre, (second
N: couple down the centre and back up the outside at same time.) First couple down
N: the centre and back up the outside, (second couple down the outside and back up
N: the centre at same time.) First and second couples down the centre together,
N: back.--First couple cast off, right and left four.

X: 477
T:Charlie Mulvihill's Jig
R:jig
C:Charlie Mulvihill?
S:irtrad-l, 8/97, Edward A Beimborn
H:Brendan found the manuscript in a Charlie Mulvihill's attic (as part
H:of his estate, as I recall).  Brendan taught this tune at the 1993
H:Milwaukee summer school, and I transcribed it for the occasion of the
H:Great IRTRAD 1994 Milwaukee Tune Swap.  I put in some, but not all,
H:of the ornaments, which he taught us to do.  More rolls and cuts.
N:from Brendan Mulvihill
Z:Alan Ng's contribution.
M:6/8
N:Posted to the woodenflute mailing list January 2002

X: 488
T:An Ri/l Cam
C:Traditional
Z:Gordon Turnbull, Edinburgh
B:CRE1 (107)
N:107.  An Ríl Cam [The Crooked Reel]:  The song Follow me down to Carlow is
N:of course sung to this air.  O'Neill has two settings, Follow me down and
N:Follow me down to Carlow (O'N i, 547 and 988). Goodman calls it Miss
N:Murphy (G ii, 156 and G iii, 182).  It is also played as a jig [e.g., as a
N:single jig in CRÉ II, 84].  In Scotland it is called Bonnie Annie.  It is
N:printed in the "Glen Collection of Scottish Dance Music" (i, p;23), from a
N:collection by Dow published c.1775. Aird also printed it (iii, 548). [from
N:Sonny Brogan, accordion][Breandan Breathnach, translation by Paul de Grae]
M:C
L:1/8
N:Posted to the woodenflute mailing list January 2002
K:ADor
(3ABA AG EF G2 | AGAB cded | BA (3B^cd eaaf | (3gfe dB BAdB |
(3ABA AG EF G2 | AGAB cded | BA (3B^cd eaaf | (3gfe dB BA A2 |]
egdg egdc | BG ~G2 Bc d2 | egdg eaaf | (3gfe dB BA A2 |
agef gedB | (3cBA (3BAG EFGB | AGAB cdef | (3gfe dB BA A2 |]

(AFD) {=C} B,2 A,| B,DD D2:| (A/4B/4c/)| (dfd) (ecA)|
(B/2A/2)(B/2c/2)({Bc}d) (B/2A/2)(G/2F/2)(E/2D/2)| E&gt;DE {DE}F&gt;ED|
(FD)B, B,2(A/4B/4c/2)| (df)d (ec)A |
(B/A/)(B/c/){Bc}d (B/A/)(G/F/)(E/D/)|E&gt;DE {DE}FDB,|A,DD ~D2 (A/4B/4c/)|
(df)d (ec)A|(B/2A/2)(B/2c/2)({Bc}d) (B/2A/2)(G/2F/2)(E/2D/2)|
(F/2D/2)(A/2F/2)(d/2A/2) (B/2A/2)(G/2F/2)(E/2D/2)| ({DE}F)EE E2 D/2B,/2|
A,&gt;B,D D&gt;ED| (EF)A d2 c/2B/2| (AF)D {=C} B,2 A,| B,DDD2||

X: 621
T:An Buachaill Dreoite
M:C
L:1/8
Q:160
S:from Mike Rafferty
R:fling
N:Play the grace note firmly - almost a smear
H:see "The Dance Music of Willie Clancy", "An Buachaill Dreoite" (page
H:99, no. 135).
N:Posted to the woodenflute mailing list January 2003
Z:Tom Madden
K:G

| B2BG c3A | d^cde fgaf | gzgf gbag | fdcA G2:||
